thread.title: Home loans dip in May as heat comes out of housing
thread.title_full: Home loans dip in May as heat comes out of housing | afr.com

author: Robert Harley
title: Home loans dip in May as heat comes out of housing
text:
Investors are making up a smaller pool of those borrowing for houses. Michele Mossop by Robert Harley The number of home loan approvals fell 6.1 per cent in May, surprising analysts and pointing to a cooling in the housing market.
The volume of investment lending rose again in the month, up 1 per cent on a trend basis according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, and faster than the nation's financial regulators would like to see.
But on a seasonally adjusted basis investment lending fell by 3.2 per cent.
The numbers are yet to reflect t he new loan to valuation limits put in place by the banks in recent weeks .
One leading mortgage broker, AFG, reported a "significant cooling for investment loans" in the month of June, with the proportion of new brokered loans for investment dropping back to 39.6 per cent nationally.
In the key market of NSW the proportion of AFG brokered loans to investors dropped from 49.8 per cent in May to 41.6 per cent in June.
Overall, the total value of dwelling finance commitments excluding alterations and additions continued to rise on trend basis, by 0.7 per cent in May, though the seasonally adjusted number dropped 4 per cent.
The number of first home buyer commitments as a percentage of total owner occupied housing finance commitments rose to 15.9 per cent in May, compared with 15.8 per cent in April.
